abstract.p: Experimental studies investigating the flexural behavior of six concrete beams were conducted with various reinforcements, including ordinary steel bars, steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bars, pure fiber-reinforced polymer bars (either carbon fiber reinforced polymer bars or basalt fiber reinforced polymer bars), and hybrid bars (steel bars and basalt fiber reinforced polymer bars). The test results show the following: (a) steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar beams exhibit stable post-yield stiffness after the yielding of the inner steel bar of the steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar and concrete crushed after the rupture of the outer fiber-reinforced polymer of the steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar; (b) the ordinary reinforced concrete beam has the largest ductility coefficient, but the ultimate load was just approximately 31% of that of the corresponding steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar beams; (c) brittle shear failure was observed for both fiber reinforced polymer bar reinforced beams because of the high ultimate tensile strength of fiber-reinforced polymer bar; (d) although the steel-fiber-reinforced polymer ratio of the hybrid beam (reinforced by steel and basalt fiber reinforced polymer bars) is the same as that of the steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar beams, the ultimate load of hybrid beam is approximately 72% of that of the corresponding steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar, which is caused by the premature slip of basalt fiber reinforced polymer bar in hybrid beam where the bond stress is large; (e) by comparing coefficients of displacement ductility and energy ductility, it is demonstrated that energy ductility coefficient is more reasonable for evaluating the performance of steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar beams take into account of the post-yield stiffness of steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar beams; and (f) high initial stiffness and good ductility for steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar reinforced concrete beams can be obtained by adjusting the steel-fiber-reinforced polymer ratio and fiber-reinforced polymer type. Furthermore, because of the steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar’s outer fiber-reinforced polymer, steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar reinforced concrete beams have a high durability.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Steel bars represent an excellent reinforcement for concrete structures in terms of modulus, tensile strength, and elastoplastic properties. However, such factors as cracking of concrete covers or poor construction process could lead to corrosion of steel bars, especially in severe environments, such as marine areas. Various techniques have been explored to enhance the anti-corrosion properties of steel bars themselves, such as epoxy-coated steel rebar1 and steel-reinforced polymer.2 However, corrosion could still lead to breakdown of the bar because of damaged spots in the coating.

Fiber reinforcement polymer (FRP) is a non-metal material that has evolved to become an effective substitution for steel rebar in severe environments. The application of FRP is becoming more and more popular for both internal reinforcement and external strengthening.3–6 Numerous studies have been conducted to investigate the flexural behavior of concrete beams reinforced by FRP bars.

The serviceability of FRP-reinforced concrete (RC) beams is poorer than that for ordinary RC beams with the same reinforcement ratio,7,8 and the dominant failure mode of FRP RC beams is concrete crushing instead of FRP rupture because of the linear elastic behavior and high strength of FRP.9 Several researchers combined the FRP bars (e.g. at the corners or near the outer surface of tensile reinforcement) and the steel bar (e.g. at the inner layers of tensile reinforcement) to enhance the anti-corrosion properties of concrete beams.10–12 Corrosion of steel bars could still happen after concrete cracking, however. Hybrid FRP reinforcements with high modulus FRP and high ductility FRP were proposed13,14 to enhance the modulus and ductility of FRP-reinforced beams. Furthermore, hybrid rods compounded by braided FRP skin and plain steel cores were proposed15,16 in which the mechanical behavior exhibits a bilinear stress–strain relationship. Based on the abovementioned research, a new kind of hybrid rebar, named steel/FRP composite bar (SFCB), was proposed by Wu et al. (2010).17 The proposed SFCB uses ribbed rebar instead of plain steel bar to improve the steel/FRP interface. The outer FRP is straight and parallel to the inner steel bar such that the high strength of FRP can be used. For SFCB-reinforced beams, yielding can be achieved by the inner steel bar, and the rupture of the outer FRP at failure stage could be accepted in a severe earthquake if the inner steel bar of SFCB already exceeds the required minimum reinforcement ratio. The anti-corrosion property of SFCB makes it a competitive material for near surface mounted strengthening of concrete structures.18

A typical uniaxial stress–strain relationship for SFCB is shown in Figure 1, which presents a stable post-yield modulus after the yielding of the inner steel bar. Based on mechanical tests, four-point loading test of six concrete beams are conducted. The tests include two beams reinforced by SFCBs, one ordinary RC beam, two pure FRP beams (basalt FRP (BFRP) and carbon FRP (CFRP)), and one hybrid beam reinforced by both steel and BFRP bars. All of the testing beams are designed with the same axial tensile stiffness of the reinforcements before yielding. Figure 1.
Stress–strain relationship of SFCB.
SFCB: steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar.

sec.title: Reinforcements
sec.p:
The mechanical properties of the reinforcements used in this article are listed in Table 1 in which d represents the reinforcement’s diameter, EI the initial modulus before yielding, EII the post-yield modulus, and fy and fu are the yield stress and ultimate stress, respectively. Two kinds of SFCBs were chosen for beam reinforcement. The notation ‘S10B51’ means that the composite bar is made of a 10 mm diameter inner steel bar longitudinally compounded with 51 bundles of 4000 tex basalt fibers, where ‘tex’ is the weight (g) of one fiber bundle per kilometer. ‘S10G55’ means that the SFCB is made of a 10 mm diameter steel bar longitudinally compounded with 55 bundles of 4800 tex glass fibers. sec.title: Specimen design
sec.p:
All six concrete beams were designed to have the same initial bending stiffness. The average tested compressive strength of six concrete cubes (150 × 150 × 150 mm3) is 48.8 MPa. The specimen geometry is shown in Figure 2. All of the beams are 2000 mm in length, the cross-sectional area is 220 × 300 mm2, the steel bars in the compressive zone are of 12 mm diameter, and the stirrups are 8 mm in diameter. Figure 2.
Specimen design.

The reinforcement details for each beam are listed in Table 2 in which ρeq is the equivalent reinforcement ratio obtained by converting the cross-sectional area of each reinforcement into that of steel bars with the principle of equal tensile stiffness.7 B-C is the baseline case, and the corresponding outer FRP types of the SFCB for S10B51 and S10G55 were BFRP and glass fiber reinforced plastic (GFRP), respectively. B-H is a hybrid beam reinforced by two steel bars and one BFRP bar, where the steel bars are the same as those of the inner steel bar of the SFCB, measuring 10 mm in diameter, while the diameter of the BFRP bar in the hybrid beam was 20 mm, which is the same diameter as the bar in the pure BFRP beam. Loading is applied with a hydraulic jack. The load was measured by a load sensor under the jack (Figure 2). The loading rate was 10 kN before yielding; the rate is changed to 5 kN after steel bar or the inner steel bar of the SFCB yielded. The deflections at mid-span and the two supports are measured by electric dial gages. For crack observation, beams are whitewashed and painted with grid lines at 30 mm spacing, and the crack widths are measured by an electric crack observer.

sec.title: Failure mode
sec.p:
Figure 3 presents the failure modes of each beam. There are four failure modes observed in the test: (a) concrete crushing after ordinary steel bars yielded (B-C, Figure 3(a)); (b) the outer FRP of the SFCB ruptured after the yielding of the inner steel bar of the SFCB with subsequent concrete crushing (B-S10B51 (Figure 3(b)) and B-S10G55 (Figure 3(c))); (c) shear failure of concrete beams without rupture of FRP bar (B-BFRP (Figure 3(d)) and B-CFRP (Figure 3(e))); and (d) slip of FRP bar after the yielding of ordinary steel bar followed by concrete crushing (B-H, Figure 3(f)). Figure 3.
Failure modes of specimens: (a) B-C; (b) B-S10B51; (c) B-S10G55; (d) B-BFRP; (e) B-CFRP; and (f) B-H.
BFRP: basalt fiber reinforced polymer; CFRP: carbon fiber reinforced polymer.

For beam B-C, the first flexural crack occurs approximately 20 mm from the mid-span when the load is approximately 33.5 kN. A total of five cracks appear in the pure flexural region after steel bar yield, when the deformation increases dramatically while the load approximately remains constant. For B-S10B51, the first crack appears at the left loading point, while the second crack is at the right loading point when the load reaches 40 kN. The third crack appears when the load is approximately 60 kN, and no new flexural cracks appear after that. The total cracking in B-S10B51 is less than that in B-C, which is probably caused by less bonding between SFCB and concrete than between ordinary steel bar and concrete.19 For B-S10G55, there are a total of five cracks in the pure flexural region and the failure mode of B-S10G55 is similar to B-S10B51. After the inner steel bar of the SFCB yields, the sound of gradual rupture of the outer FRP of the SFCB could be heard, and the FRP rupture is at the position where the biggest flexural crack is located.

For the two pure FRP RC beams, flexural cracks initially appear at the pure bending region. Flexural–shear cracks then appear as the load increases, and shear failure eventually occurs to both B-BFRP and B-CFRP (Figure 3(d) and (e)). For beam B-H with the hybrid steel bar and BFRP bar reinforcement, the crack load is approximately 43 kN, and four flexural cracks appear when the load reaches 55 kN. After the yielding of the steel bar, asymmetrical development of cracks can be observed. The flexural crack development near the right loading point is faster than that near the left loading point, which results in the premature slip of the BFRP bar.

sec.title: Load–deflection curves
sec.p:
The load–deflection (LD) curves for each beam are illustrated in Figure 4. There are three key points in the curves: cracking, yielding, and SFCB outer FRP rupture. These three points divide the loading process into four stages: elastic stage before cracking, service stage after cracking, post-yield stage before FRP rupture, and the stage after the rupture of FRP. Figure 4.
LD curves of specimens.
LD: load–deflection.

Before cracking, the curve slopes of the four beams are similar to each other as designed. The cracking moments Mcr of all beams are approximately 21 kN·m, as presented in Table 3. Compared with B-C, SFCB beams have apparent stable post-yield stiffness after the yielding point. The slopes of post-yield stiffness for beams B-S10B51, B-S10G55, and B-H are similar to each other, while the ultimate (peak) loads are different. The ultimate loads for beams B-S10B51 and B-S10G55 are approximately 2.87 and 1.99 times of that of RC beam B-C, respectively.

LD curves for the pure FRP RC beams (B-BFRP and B-CFRP) are almost linear with shear failure at the end. The corresponding ultimate loads are more than 3.7 times of that of B-C. The stiffness of B-BFRP is slight smaller than that of B-CFRP. For the larger amount of CFRP bars in B-CFRP (seven CFRP bars), the diameter of CFPR bar is much smaller than that of BFRP bar, which results in better bonding behavior of CFRP bar to the surrounding concrete than that of BFRP to concrete (there are only three BFRP bars in B-BFRP).

For B-H with hybrid steel bar and BFRP bar reinforcement, when the load reached 180 kN, the slope of the LD curve became smaller. A loud sound could be heard when the load was 190 kN, which was probably the premature slipping of BFRP bar, and the load decreased to the level corresponding to only steel bars’ being effective. The ultimate tensile force of BFRP bar was approximately 285 kN, and the development length of BFRP bar in B-H is not large enough to achieve thorough anchorage. The slip of BFRP bar also resulted in a sinusoidal LD curve of B-H after the peak load, which was similar to the observation during the bond test between FRP bar and concrete.19 After FRP rupture (or FRP bar slip), the loading decreased to the level corresponding to only inner steel bars being effective.

sec.title: Crack
sec.p:
Load–crack width curves are shown in Figure 5. For beam B-C, crack width increased dramatically after yielding when the loading could not increase, which is similar to the development of mid-span deflection. For beams B-S10B51, B-10G55, and B-H, crack development is restrained by the FRP part. With increasing loading, the crack width becomes smaller when new cracks appear. For the two SFCB beams, the crack width difference is small before yielding, and the crack width develops from 0.3 mm to approximately 1.0 mm when the loading varies from 76 to 350 kN. The crack width of B-H is the smallest before yielding at only 0.1 mm, which is due to good bonding behavior of the steel bars to the surrounding concrete. The crack amount of B-CFRP was larger than that of B-BFRP (Figure 3(d) and (e)), that is, the crack width development of B-CFRP is slightly slower than that of B-BFRP, which is caused by the smaller diameter and greater number of CFRP bars in B-CFRP than that of BFRP bars in B-BFRP. Figure 5.
Load–crack width curves of specimens.

The allowable width of internal cracks and external cracks for RC beams are 0.4 and 0.33 mm in ACI 318.20 The allowable width of internal cracks and external cracks for FRP-reinforced beams are 0.5 and 0.7 mm in ACI code.4 For SFCB beams, because of the good corrosion resistance of the outer FRP, the maximum crack width limits can be slightly larger than that of RC beam. For the higher initial modulus of SFCB, the crack behavior of SFCB beams is better than that of FRP beams.

sec.title: Stiffness, energy dissipation, and ductility coefficient
sec.p:
The stiffness of a concrete beam is defined as the slope of the LD curve, the same definition as for concrete columns.21 The initial stiffness before yielding K1 and post-yield stiffness K2 are given by equations (1) and (2) (1)K1=PyΔy (2)K2=Pu-PyΔu-Δy where Py and Pu are the yield and ultimate load and Δy and Δu the corresponding yield and ultimate displacement, respectively. Δu is determined as the rupture point (peak load) of the LD curve, while Δy is obtained by the graphing method (Figure 6(a)), where a tangent line OA to the LD curve can be drawn and its intersection point with the post-yield part of the LD curve line AM is point A. Draw the vertical line AB to the displacement axis, and the intersection point with the LD curve is point B, and a tangent line BC to the LD curve at point B can be drawn with point C as the intersection point with the post-yield part of the LD curve line AM. The yield displacement Δy is located as the intersection point Y of vertical line CY to the LD curve. Figure 6.
Schematic displacement ductility and energy ductility of SFCB beam: (a) the way to determine yield displacement Δy and (b) displacement ductility and energy ductility.
SFCB: steel-fiber reinforced polymer composite bar.

The ductility of concrete beams is defined as the deformation capacity from the yield point to the peak load point (or the 85% of the peak load), and the displacement ductility coefficient could be defined by equation (3). To consider the influence of post-yield stiffness, the energy ductility coefficient was taken as another index22,23 that can be observed in equation (4) (3)μΔ=ΔuΔy (4)μE=EuEy where the yield energy Ey is the triangular area under the LD curve, and the ultimate energy Eu the total area under the LD curve (Figure 6).

The energy dissipation–mid-span deflection curves are shown in Figure 7. The energy dissipation capacities of the beams are similar to each other before yielding. After beam yielding, the energy dissipation capacity is related to the magnitude of the post-yield stiffness where the higher post-yield stiffness is associated with better energy dissipation capacity. FRP-bar-reinforced beams have higher post-yield stiffness values and have larger energy dissipation before shear failure occurred. For SFCB beams and hybrid-reinforced beam B-H, the energy dissipation curves almost overlap with each other before failure, and B-S10B51 has the largest energy dissipation (1.41 times of that of RC beam B-C) when the mid-span displacement reaches 42 mm. Figure 7.
Energy dissipation of the specimens.

Calculated stiffness and ductility coefficients can be observed in Table 4. The post-yield stiffness K2 of beam B-C is approximately 0.357 kN/mm (approximately 2.6% of K1), while that of beams B-S10B51, B-S10G55, and B-H are approximately 40% of the initial stiffness K1. The yield displacements of concrete beams reinforced by SFCBs or hybrid reinforcement are larger than that of B-C because the plastic development of the steel bar was restrained by the outer FRP (or the BFRP bar for B-H). For two pure FRP beams, shear failure occurs at the ultimate state, and the ultimate deformation capacity is controlled by the stirrups in the shear–flexural region (shear resistance capacity). As a result, the corresponding values for the pure FRP beams are not comparable to those for the other beams. For B-H with hybrid steel bar and BFRP bar reinforcement, the ductility coefficient is comparatively small due to the premature slip of BFRP bar. For B-S10B51, the displacement ductility coefficient μΔ was approximately 64.8% of that of B-C, while the energy ductility coefficient μE was approximately 87.5% of that of B-C. Therefore, it is more reasonable to use μE for the deformation capacity evaluation of concrete beams with significant post-yield stiffness. Table 4.

sec.title: Performance/cost ratio
sec.p: A comparison of performance/cost ratio has also been conducted for the abovementioned concrete beams (Table 5). The prices of the FRP bar were provided by a composite company in Nanjing, China. The 2012 prices of CFRP bar, GFRP bar, and BFRP bar were ¥ 400,000/ton, ¥ 30,000/ton, and ¥ 60,000/ton, respectively. For SFCBs, the prices were compounded by the costs of steel bars and FRP parts, in which the cost of the pultrusion process was assumed to be the same as that of pure FRP bar. The 2012 price of concrete in the beams was ¥ 380/m3.

The performance/cost ratios of the peak load Cp and energy absorption capacity CE are calculated by equations (5) and (6) (5)CP=PuPrice (6)CE=EuPrice where Price includes the price of bars, FRP, concrete, and stirrups used in the beam, Pu is the ultimate load and Eu the ultimate energy dissipation capacity.

Because shear failure happened to both pure FRP-reinforced beams, yet there was no rupture to the FRP bar, it is not exactly equivalent to compare the performance/cost ratio between FRP and SFCB beams where rupture of the outer FRP of SFCB did happen (i.e. full utilization of the FRP part). Nevertheless, the performance/cost ratio comparison between the regular RC beam, SFCB beams, and FRP bar beams shows that the following: (a) appropriately designed ordinary steel bar RC beam has the most effective performance/cost ratio with good ductility, but it might not be suitable to be constructed in corrosive environments; (b) the cost of B-S10B51 was somewhat higher than that of B-S10G55, but the performance/cost ratio of B-S10B51 is larger than B-S10G55, especially in terms of the energy absorption capacity ratio CE; (c) the performance/cost ratio of B-BFRP is better than that of B-CFRP with a similar ultimate load capacity, which indicates that basalt fiber is a better choice in practice; and (d) for hybrid reinforcement, though premature slip happened, the performance/cost ratio was still higher than that of B-S10G55, revealing that the performance/cost ratio of steel/BFRP composite bar is the most cost-effective reinforcement than that of other FRP bars and hybrid bars.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The failure modes of SFCB beams are completely different from those of RC beams, depending on such factors as the longitudinal reinforcement ratio and the steel/FRP ratio. Assuming no shear failure, the failure modes of SFCB beams include the following: (a) concrete crushing after SFCB yielding, but before the rupture of SFCB’s outer FRP. The longer elongation rate of the outer FRP, the more probabilistic of this failure mode would happen; (b) concrete crushing after the rupture of SFCB’s outer FRP (B-S10B51 and B-S10G55); and (c) concrete crushing before SFCB yielding, which is similar to that of FRP-bar-reinforced beam (a linear LD curve would be obtained before concrete crushing).

For a concrete frame, a ‘strong column, weak beam’ is preferred to prevent the damage of the columns. Hence, for SFCB RC beams, the post-yield stiffness (steel/FRP ratio) of a SFCB-reinforced beam should be specially designed to satisfy the ‘strong column, weak beam’ rule. If a SFCB-reinforced beam is designed just for anti-corrosion, then the FRP content can be at the minimum value that satisfies the corrosion prevention requirement. For SFCB beams with low FRP content, the design theory can be the same as that of ordinary RC beams. However, when the FRP content is large enough to make the SFCB beam have a significant increase of load carrying capacity after yielding (such as in the above SFCB beams, the ultimate load is approximately three times of the yielding load), the significant increase of strength after yielding should be considered. For SFCB beams with large post-yield stiffness, which is approaching linear and elastic, the design theory subsequently become similar to that of pure FRP beams.

For SFCB, hybrid-reinforced, and pure FRP beams, the premature slip of the reinforcement should be avoided. That is, the bond–slip behavior, the development length, and the anchorage method of SFCB with different parameters should be examined in future studies.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
Four-point loading test on six concrete beams reinforced by different types of composite bars were conducted. The testing beams were designed with equal initial stiffness before yielding. The failure modes, load–mid-span deflection, crack development, and performance/cost ratios were studied in detail. The study found the following points:
With similar initial stiffness values of the six concrete beams as observed in experiments, SFCB beams and the hybrid-reinforced beam demonstrated stable and larger post-yield stiffness values compared to the regular RC beam.
The observed failure mode of SFCB beams was concrete crushing after the rupture of the outer FRP of SFCB. When the FRP content becomes larger, concrete could be crushed before the rupture of FRP. For pure FRP beams, the shear capacity should be specially designed with a higher reinforcement ratio to avoid shear failure.
For SFCB beams with stable post-yield stiffness, the energy ductility coefficient is a better performance index than the displacement ductility coefficient as it appropriately takes into consideration the higher ultimate strength brought by FRP wraps.
SFCB is an applicable composite reinforcement for concrete beams, which demonstrates similar anti-corrosion characteristics as pure FRP-bar-reinforced beams. The steel/BFRP composite bar reinforced also possesses a superior performance/cost ratio in terms of both ultimate load capacity and energy dissipation capacity.
